results.title: [Orsola: Teramo, 1960]
results.brief_description:
In the course of a day, Orsola writes her fiancé, Ulderico Ciabarra, a letter, goes out to post it and reads a magazine in the sunshine. The filmmaker, Francesco Di Silvano, was a family acquaintance and cinema enthusiast who proposed the film as a gift Orsola could send her fiancé, recently settled in Melbourne, Australia. The children that appear in the final sequence are related to the filmmaker.

Note: An excerpt from ‘Orsola: Teramo, 1960’ appears in ‘Innamorati’ (2001/3); a four minute digital storytelling work created by Roberta Ciabarra, ACMI Film Programer and daughter of Orsola and Ulderico, as part of a pilot workshop conducted at ACMI in 2001.For technical reasons a re-record of the narration was done in 2003.

Donor has requested that any de-accessioning of the 8mm film that it be returned to him or the family. File Note with Governance.
results.description:
A ‘day in the life’ of a young woman whose fiancé has emigrated to Melbourne, Australia. In the course of a day, Orsola writes her fiancé, Ulderico, a letter, goes out to post it and reads a magazine in the sunshine.

The filmmaker, Francesco Di Silvano, was a family acquaintance and cinema enthusiast who proposed the film as a gift Orsola could send her fiancé, recently settled in Melbourne, Australia.

The related work “Innamorati” - made by Orsola’s daughter - tells the moving story of Orsola’s marriage and her journey to Australia to be reunited with her husband.
description_for_label:

The filmmaker, Francesco Di Silvano, was a family acquaintance and cinema enthusiast who proposed the film as a gift Orsola could send her fiancé, recently settled in Melbourne, Australia. The children that appear in the final sequence are related to the filmmaker.

Note: An excerpt from ‘Orsola: Teramo, 1960’ appears in ‘Innamorati’ (2001/3); a four minute digital storytelling work created by Roberta Ciabarra, ACMI Film Programer and daughter of Orsola and Ulderico, as part of a pilot workshop conducted at ACMI in 2001.For technical reasons a re-record of the narration was done in 2003.

Donor has requested that any de-accessioning of the 8mm film that it be returned to him or the family. File Note with Governance.

results.title: [Noise] = Hearing conservation
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Tom Manefield, Dept of Science and Technology and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Serious hearing loss perpetrated in the industrial workplace is irreversible. This program portrays the peer pressures on the shop floor that might discourage workers from using protective devices - but at their peril. We see one factory worker who is teased about wearing his ear muffs, but his fantasies convince him that the consequences are worse than the flak he cops. A light-hearted drama which emphasises the necessity of using the correct protective gear at work. Stars Bryan Brown.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Karl McPhee, Tom Manefield, Dept of Science and Technology and Film Australia

results.title: [Musterrolle: a compilation of short films by Peter Tscherkassky]
results.brief_description: 15 titles create this retrospective of experimental shorts by Austrian filmmaker Peter Tscherkassky. Titles date from 1981 through to the 1999 trailer for the Viennese Film Festival - Viennale. The films work through an experimentation with dissolves, double exposures, the ambiguity of light, found footage and the looping of vision and sound. Sound features heavily in Tscherkassky’s work and the principal composer here is Armin Schminkl. Schminkl also features as a subject for several films in the retrospective. Titles are as follows: Outerspace; The Arrival (L’Arrivee); Happy End; Parallel Space: interview; Tabula Rasa; Shot-Countershot; Kelimba; Manufraktur; Motion Picture; Urlaubsfilm; Freeze Frame; Liebesfilm; Erotique; Aderlab; Get Ready - Viennale ‘99 Trailer.

results.title: Outer space
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio
results.brief_description: Prolific Austrian avant-garde filmmaker and theorist, Peter Tscherkassky, reinvents a 1981 Barbara Hershey horror vehicle, leaving the original’s crystalline surface intact only to violently shatter its narrative illusion. Sounds of crickets, static and distorted music give way to explosions, screams, and garbled voices. The actress’ face multiplies across the screen as the frame is invaded by sprocket holes, an optical soundtrack, and flashes of solarized imagery.
results.description: Prolific Austrian avant-garde filmmaker and theorist, Peter Tscherkassky, reinvents a 1981 Barbara Hershey horror vehicle, leaving the original’s crystalline surface intact only to violently shatter its narrative illusion. The actress’ face multiplies across the screen as the frame is invaded by sprocket holes, an optical soundtrack, and flashes of solarized imagery.
